projects.title: Building Smart Motors
projects.subtitle: story of how we changed the world with a $20 product
projects.desc:
This amazing piece of tech will revolutionize the way you program robots. Imagine a world where you can program a robot the way you train your dog, or your kid, maybe just your dog.

The way you program this robot is by teaching what action follows what reaction.. for example, you can teach your motor to go to 60 degrees when you push a button, and turn to 120 degrees when you hold it for more than 1 second. This works by training the motor. That is how you would code it!!! Done !

projects.title: Draw2Code
projects.subtitle: Low-cost and expressive tangible computational kit
projects.desc:
Computational thinking is nowadays considered an essential skill in the K-12 educational curriculum. While many computational kits and platforms have been developed in the past decades, most of the tangible kits that are designed for early childhood are either expensive to be deployed at home and in classroom environments or only provide pre-defined challenges with limited creative content creation opportunities. We investigated low-cost and expressive tangible interfaces that foster computational literacy.

Draw2Code is a paper-based tangible computational kit for young children to create an interactive 2D augmented reality animation. Children use Draw2Code to make their paper drawing alive as an animated virtual sprite and control it using hand gestures. Engaging with the kit, children can design, code, and play with their creations. It exposes children to basic programming concepts through playful and tangible interaction.

projects.title: Collaborative Online Robotics Platform
projects.desc: An integrated educational learning development web-based environment intended for learning and teaching through robotics. CORP combines the potential of the Google web-based platform with the educational robot technology of the LEGO Mindstorms EV3 Kit. Designed for students in primary and high school, CORP allows students from different locations to interact collaboratively through sharing a Google Slide document with a custom add-on developed to talk to the EV3 robot.
